Content: [Buzzing noise] [Schafer laughing]
Schafer: Oh my god.
Schafer: There you go.
Schafer: I forgot to put my beard on this morning, you're right.
I left that beard at home.
People are going to know it's a fake beard.
Rice: I think that it's also just important to keep in mind that there's like other impacts besides just funding the game and that
like if we now go get a publisher for this game, then it's suddenly like voids everything we've said about the project
and everything we're trying to do.
Schafer: Where did we leave off?
Oh, that's right.
Game was too big, company's going to close down, didn't have any money and Cloud Colony wasn't done.
Bailey: Like because right now, you know, it looks like the plane's kind of diving down a little bit
and we just need to, we have time to pull up.
Schafer: What does the plane diving down stand for?
Bailey: That stands for Schafer: Us crashing?
Schafer: The whole company crashing into the ground and burning? Bailey: [laughing] Rice: A lot actually.
Well, I mean right after that episode aired, yeah, right after that episode aired we started Amnesia Fortnight
so the team kind of took a break from everything for a little bit there.
Schafer: Amnesia Fortnight is coming up, people.
And you forget what we were working on for two weeks, that's where the name comes from.
We split the company into small groups, sometimes four or five groups.
And each group has to make a game in two weeks.
Rice: I think ultimately that was an amazing process and people had a great time and just came back really energized after that.
And a lot of progress has already been made in this month since then.
Things are definitely moving along quicker and we're starting to address a lot of potential ways to help make production go smoothly
and on a lower budget than it's looking like it could.
Schafer: There's scope and then there's money, then there's efficiencies.
And I've never seen this solved any other way than all of the above.
Stamos: Yeah. Schafer: You know what I mean?
Some scope reduction, some efficiency improvements, some extra money.
We've been working on simplifying some stuff.
J.P.'s come on and we've been trying to look at things in the spaceship we can simplify.
We cut some room, cut the teleporter rooms, cut some simple stuff.
But it's more like an ongoing thing, simplifying it as we go.
You know, you want to make the game, most of the backers I think would be unanimous in saying they want a great game, right?
So they're trusting me to use the judgment of like how much to cut that still makes it a great game.
And they don't want us to cut more than that, so we just have to, we've been working on that problem.
Bailey: I'm not privy to what's actually going on in the scoping side right now.
Although I hear that they're, they're making some progress.
On the funding side I was able to bring in a few deals that don't require any kind of creative control.
So like Brutal Legend PC, which to me is potentially, you know, better on PC than it would be on console, because it's an RTS.
It has RTS elements.
It's never actually been released and it's got, you know, huge amount of music already licensed in it
So we moved that up and you know, we're looking to release that pretty soon.
And all or, no, some or all of those profits will probably go back to Red's.
Schafer: I mean...for one of our other games, he found a licensing deal in Korea
So there's extra money and revenue that can come in through that.
And that's the kind of stuff I would never have, I can't whip up a Korean licensing deal on my own, I'd have no idea.
How do you, who do you even call? Do you know any-?
We got such a response to Majus's print from the last episode that we can now, now selling the print.
Each one is a new line of dialogue that I can put in the game, so think about it that way.
Bailey: I don't know how much money is actually going to be enough.
So for me, like my mandate is more.
Because I want Tim to be able to completely check out and when he feels the game's done, then it's done.
Stamos: New addition to my office.
It's pretty exciting.
There's nothing much on it yet.
Oh, except there's a red milestone right there.
I want to see how that goes.
We're working on all kinds of things throughout the whole studio.
But when it comes to Red's we're I come in as more of a "how can we control costs?"
Hansen: This still is adding up to six and a half months of tech work so [laughing] we gotta find out.
Franzke: Oh that's just even split across all the ...
Hanson: Well it was eight and a half months before Franzke: But that actually makes sense to me, that this is kind of like a relief [laughs].
Stamos: More, more needs to be done to really understand what's left to do and how long that will take.
Really like kind of refactoring all of our assumptions about that schedule.
Really I think getting some project management attention on it.
Matt Hansen coming in and working on that uber-schedule so we can really plan out what's happening a little bit more down the road.
Hansen: Obviously Greg's already the producer on the project.
But you know, it's super-important for the studio, really important for us.
And you know, it's one of our completely self-funded projects so it's one of the things where it did make sense
to bring on additional production help to make sure that we're, we're running as effectively and efficiently as possible.
I have some expertise from working in adventure games in the past so I think that's something they wanted to bring onto the team
to help make it go smoothly as possible.
I'm actually pulling a lot from my experiences on those games to understand how to schedule the game, scope it properly and stuff like that.
Hansen: I still have this remote deployment harness as something I'm going to have to talk to Tim about.
I really want to push forward on that.
I think it's going to be really helpful for debugging the game later on.
Franzke: I agree.
Otherwise we're just going to shoot ourselves in the foot. Hansen: Yeah.
Rice: And yeah, it's been helpful.
I think it's just like , it's nice to be able to kind of hand it off to him and kind of get ahead of things a little bit.
It's going to be really helpful.
Hansen: Developing an engine and a game at the same time, it's always been a challenge for a lot of different games.
You'll hear that as a common story for a lot of games where they're, you know, it's like, Limbo's a good example,
where they were trying to develop the engine for Limbo, they're also trying to create the game at the same time.
It's huge, hugely challenging.
Hansen: All right. That's it.
Thank you very much.
I'll start laying this out and then let's talk about maybe later.
Franzke: Yep. Hansen: Later next week. Thanks a lot.
Stamos: So that's been huge. I think that having additional gameplay programmers added to the team,
but who have design experience, that that's probably helping.
Rice: Yeah, we just added a handful of people to the team, kind of staffing up a bit.
And it was people that were on The Cave and that just shipped a few weeks ago.
[Applause] Gilbert: Well, we shipped The Cave.
[Cheering] Gilbert: On 742 platforms, so that's good news.
Anyway, I just, you know, a toast to everybody and they just did an amazing job on The Cave.
Group: Cheers!
And now what you have all really been waiting for, cake.
Group: [laughs] Schafer: Scoop it up with his hands
Put it in everyone's mouth Line up.
Rice: And so they just are wrapping up their final tasks and bug fixes for that And as they become available, we're just trying to figure out
what makes the most sense for him to be working on and right now that is Reds.
So we've got someone from every discipline added to the team and kind of helping to lighten people's loads and add some extra manpower to the game.
Schafer: Everyone's here, OK. Awesome.
Dailies. Film crew's back.
Not that you notice.
I'm sure you guys are all, for those of you who have not ever been filmed before, if you ignore them, really,
They'll just, they'll catch you picking your nose.
Rice: We're too big now. I don't know how they're going to do this.
Schafer: I know, look how huge we are.
Let's get this over with. OK.
Yesterday I was going to write those last three things for the Cloud Colony, but I did a whole bunch of other project review stuff.
LeBreton: It was pretty easy to pick up on, you know.
Anna was teaching me a whole bunch about the systems that she wrote on the game play,
which is mainly what I've been working with.
Just figuring out how, how dialogue, I've been, a lot of my work has been wiring up the dialogue trees, you know.
We got the writing from Tim and then we got scratch VO, so I wired that up so you can pick, "tell me more"
or "what about this" or "see you later." Thomas: I guess you're better at spotting fakes than the other birds.
Hey, can you take me here to my home?
You can? Great!
Ever seen this place? Great.
Can you take me there right now?
LeBreton: I enjoy all phases of a project.
You know, if it's a good project then it's fun to be in on the early inception where you're getting to like, you know,
help really make big important creative decisions.
It's fun to be in the middle where you're producing stuff, you know, you're building it
and eventually hit that critical mass where it's like, yes, we have a game now; we know what we're building.
And then late in the game, if you're not, you know, if you're not stressing out too much about like, you know,
fires that you have to put out, it's really fun to like see the last few steps come together
and really feel like some, like you're putting polish on something.
So all of those are cool.
But yeah, I think we're very much in the middle.
We're kind of like in the early middle in this.
So yeah, no.
And I've worked, you know, I've, yeah, I've led stuff before but also just been in the trenches guy.
So you know, depends, again, if it's a good project, then I'll enjoy, and I can contribute something substantial to it.
That's all I really care about.
Garner: It was on budget, on time; everything was great.
You're going to, you're going to go home early, no overtime.
Then I saw Episode 7 and I was like, aha.
Just the normal stuff.
They were just like, would you be interested in DFA, Tim wants you on that project so bad.
He's always talking about Dave being in on the project.
Schafer: We got Dave Garner, famous fan of Ico and Shadow of the Colossus.
Garner: That shit is so awesome.
Schafer: And adventure games.
Yes, Garner's here because adventure games are not dead.
Garner: Adventure games are not dead.
Garner: When I came on, I initially, like the characters have so much style in them.
The first thing that I thought about was like, I'm just going to like focus on animating real subtle stuff
and like focus on the face and like focus on the eyes.
That stuff's important in like films and stuff but we don't usually do that stuff in games.
But I feel like that's one of the things that we want to try to do with this one.
Garner: This is when we were experimenting with like, you know, what kind of an attitude should he have?
Like sort of blank look on his face, that's like kind of bored because he's on the ship and getting sick of this stuff.
And he's got like, you know, his idles would be like, he's just like, overall he's not too stoked on all the stuff that's going on, on the ship.
But then when you start playing with him and explore, like we were saying it'll start getting really cool
when he's just going to be like, oh my God!
This is awesome!
A lot of people aren't really going to notice that, but like, hopeful some person is like, oh yeah, that's really cool.
Like that boy, like I've seen him change throughout the game, which is not something not I've really done with a character in a game before.
Is like have them go from, you know, one character type and, like actually end the hero's journey having gone through it,
make, you know, an emotional journey as well.
Which is something you see in movies, just not so much in games.
Schafer: Who else got added?
We got Lydia.
We've had Lydia for a little while.
Lydia's a great effects artist, technical artist.
Does a little programming on the side.
Small teams, everyone has to do a bunch of stuff.
Choy: Generally I just go through and just try to add things wherever I can, because like with this Cloud Colony.
The more, the more there's like little support ambient effects, the more alive it feels.
Schafer: I think this ground looks so pretty now.
And the little dust, and the poofs and everything.
And look at that thing up there!
What's happening up there?
Is that 3D?
Petty: Well, it's an old PlaysStation One trick.
We just took the texture and put it on crisscross polygons.
And just spun it around in 3D.
Schafer: Oh now I hate it.
Now that I know.
Cheating, now I hate it.
It looks amazing.
Melian: So here's like a new thing we're trying out.
It's actually using a 3D, a 3D element.
And you'll see it again.
So we're experimenting with that now.
Melian: I think so. I think that's the idea.
If we can get these 3D elements working and kind of blending in there without popping out too much, I think that's the idea.
And we'll go in and try to do that more and more.
Schafer: Whoa color!
Oh there's a mom!
Hey, hi, mom.
She's got hair that comes off of the crystal ball.
Peck: I guess last week was like really my first time, my first week where like I really got to spend like a lot of my time on Red's.
Really fun.
Basically Lee's been working really hard getting the environment white boxed so you can actually just walk around.
And I'm just following behind him wiring up the basic puzzle structure as it comes in.
Yeah, this is the first piece of color art we've got on this.
Like a rough color.
But still amazing.
It really reminds me of like, you have a giant art book, like hard cover picture book in front of you
and just like turning the page and being really immersed in the art.
Like you know, with the old pixel-based adventure games, they didn't have like this camera flowing over things
and zooming in and panning out as much.
And this really feels like I'm being like guided through this, this really beautiful experience.
So that's what's really captured my imagination so far, is like this story is just being presented in such a beautiful way.
I'm really excited to see like where, how far we can push that.
Peck: Let me just load up a certain level accepting.
Yeah, I'll open up the galley. Yeah.
Yeah, the bedroom and the galley have the rough color.
It's amazing. It's like super cool.
Look how rough this is, but there's still this like epic scale.
You know, you're supposed to be floating out in space in a space suit, but everything but man.
This really blew me away when I saw that. So yeah.
I'm excited to talk to Bagel when he comes in and be like, awesome job, man.
Stapley: So yeah, I guess lightings down here and just try to tie it a little in with that one.
I feel like these are, I mean they're not totally different.
This color, I kinda like this being more white.
I feel like this is a little too orange.
I mean, I guess it's just the orange light, but still, yeah.
Maybe a little bit more yellow.
Hey, Tim. I'll get him later. I say go for it.
Brand: It's a really good learning experience.
I really like Bagel's style.
Yeah, he drew like a really awesome style guide that might pretty up the different areas of the ship.
You know, the vibe each one should give off and like the color palettes.
And a lot of the references he was using to derive that look.
So like the player living area, utility area and then there's an off-limits area for later in the game.
He took that and then did the, some even more like specific breakdowns with just a bunch of inspirational windows
that, with those shapes and colors that he likes.
Stapley: I always go to orange.
Orange and brown and red is like shit that I always fucking do.
I mean, I feel like, I mean it's a little crutch that I have.
Not a crutch but it's like my go-to color.
All the time.
But yeah man.
You can nail it.
Stapley: Your colors are awesome.
Rice: And I'm excited to see the space stuff starting to come together, too, because Tim just delivered the dialogue for the boy's,
like first segment of the game and it's amazing.
It's hilarious.
And you can so easily see how fun it's going to be to play through.
Rice: Yeah, but like reading through it, I don't see any holes.
Like I feel like, Schafer: It's fucking perfect.
Rice: I feel like the game play programmer could script that all up now without needing any questions, which is awesome.
Schafer: So no questions will be allowed.
Schafer: I think spaceship boy's stuff is easier, like the basic setup of it leads it to, it's funny because it's just, there's more humor in it.
And you would think you could just make everything funny equally but like the boy stuff's just naturally funnier
because he's all alone with his mom, the tension between him and his mom
and all the little robots and all the silly scenes he finds himself in.
I have to figure out something for the girl's world that makes it that easy to put, to put jokes in there.
Here's a picture of the climax of the game.
Do you want to see my pictures?
Total spoiler right there.
Can you see that?
Stamos: Yeah, I think that the change that I've seen the most is Tim, you know, absolutely.
Because he, he seems really motivated to kind of get things going.
And also he's, he's getting really close to the point of the entire game's designed out.
And I think that will be a big, pretty big milestone.

[Wet grinding] Schafer: The juice fast is all part of, you know,
when New Year's comes around you make a bunch of resolutions.
And it's, my resolution was not to die before my daughter got in college.
And also watching this documentary and seeing my gut enter the room like five minutes before I did.
It was just like, ah, got to do something about that.
So now I look all shrunken and my neck's all wiggly.
So you just can't win.
You just can't win and I got a gallstone probably, so.
Just lose, lose scenario, documentaries.
[Whooshing slows down] Schafer: I need a glass. Did anyone else want juice?
Schafer: Yeah. I used to get a lot more sleepy in the afternoons and I don't know if that's coffee or that's just being super fat.
Schafer: Alright. Pack up some juice to take with me.
Cheers.
How much weight did I lose while I was drinking that?
Did you notice?
You see like shrinkage? Like, blugh.
Schafer: According to the Internet, I'm like 230 right now.
Schafer: Like one site said my weight should be 160 pounds.
And I started this at 260.
So I'm down 30 pounds.
Daughter: What?
Schafer: You get to come shave off my beard.
Daughter: Papa, I don't know how to shave.
Schafer: Well, there's a time in every girl's life when she needs to learn how to shave.
Schafer: Here we go. Here we go.
[Buzzing] I'm really not going to do it.
I'm not going to do it. This is terrible.
This is a horrible mistake. Look at that.
Schafer: I used to just grow a beard every Christmas, like a Christmas beard, it'd start around Thanksgiving.
Ray got me started on that.
And then one year I grew the Christmas beard and I gained so much weight while I had it on that when I went to shave it off, I was like holy crap!
Where was all this hiding?
And then I was like, I'm going grow it back.
'Cause you actually believe that if you grow a beard, you can totally hide the fact that you're fat.
No one will figure it out.
I didn't mean to look at the people with beards when I said that.
And as, like when I get down to that weight again, I'll shave it off.
And so I shaved it off.
Schafer: I feel really dumb with this.
Try to get respect in a meeting.
I think here's a new design, you guys.
[Laughter offscreen] [Buzzing]
This is now, this is my look from like the '90s.
It was most of '90s.
I'm going to go all the way, you guys.
Schafer: If you think about it, the car is just a metaphor for my body.
They're both essentially really good looking, but they've been, you know, neglected a little bit over the years.
It's got some scratches.
There's a big knife hole in the top of it, just like me.
It's a little rusty.
It doesn't start in the morning.
It's full of gas.
Etcetera, etcetera.
And my car is something that I've been like just looking at, I should really take care of that eventually.
Kind of like, like, ah, I should really lose this weight eventually.
So I tweeted like anyone know a good mechanic?
And of course, John Romero and Brenda Romero, like we have this guy who's perfect for a MoPar, which is what my Barracuda is.
And I went down there and John showed up.
And of course I'm all excited about getting my car fixed.
And then John pulls up in this amazing like, pretty much a brand-new, like Road Runner, like '68, '69 Road Runner.
And it's all shiny.
The engine is cleaner than anything in my house.
Like you could eat off it.
It's beautiful.
And my car's sitting there all sad.
Schafer: My sad old car.
Schafer: Which brings out a whole bunch of different issues for me.
Like why aren't I rich like John Romero?
Next year I'll get on that.
This year I'm just going to get the car fixed.
And I started feeling the money flow out of my body as the guy was talking about all the work he wanted to do on it.
Schafer: How expensive is this going to be? I just want to get it running.
Schafer: So I need this game to be a hit to get out of the debt I'm going to accrue by getting that car running again.
[Engine roars] Schafer: I think the situation with our cars
really shows our levels of financial success in the industry.
Schafer: And then John took me for the most terrifying drive of my life.
[Engine accelerates] Schafer: Jesus Christ!
[Romero laughs] Schafer: It was like, in the car, he hit the gas and it felt like,
like a sledge hammer just punched in the back of my neck.
Just snapped back like Aaaagghh!
[Engine roar; screaming] And then John's driving.
I'm sure John is a really good driver, but I'm not 100 percent sure about that.
[Engine roar] Schafer: I thought I was gonna die.
Romero: Yeah! [Laughs] Thanks for the ride, John.

Offscreen: Looks like a baby!
Schafer: All right. I know I don't have the authority anymore.
Just look at me.
You'll get used to it.
Schafer: I shaved the beard, I'm on a diet.
Fixed the car.
I'm getting my writing done.
It's just a new, all new me.
For a couple months.
Then i'll just go back.
Schafer: Red's. Let go to projects. Red's, We finished the sprint on Friday and we're now looking at the build
and trying to see how we get ready to actually play-test and maybe a HOF-style play-test with you guys.
Who would like to do that.
Maybe even, well, soon. Soon.
Let's just say soon.
Rice: That stands for Hour of Fun.
It's something that's been happening here at Double Fine for a long time.
Schafer: All right. Everyone excited about the HOF?
First HOF.
Who's new, raise your hand, if you've never been in a HOF?
So you've all done HOFs before.
Let me tell you about the Hour of Fun.
Schafer: So way back on Psychonauts, we found a lot of people had not played the game, like some of the animators had never booted up and played it.
I was like, how are we going to understand our game unless everybody plays it?
So we had the mandatory Hour of Fun on a Friday.
Everybody had to stop working and play the game for an hour.
And then we did this thing where we met afterwards and be like, ask everybody what they thought.
And it was really terrifying that people actually talked about it, but really good because we got a lot of good feedback.
And so we did it all through Brutal.
We'd play the game and then everybody would just get to say whatever they felt about it.
Schafer: When you're milling around, talking to people, try not to, we try to not to influence people too much when they're playing the game,
because we'd really like to get, I think the most important feedback is getting people to talk about what they're trying to do,
because that's the stuff you miss in adventure games a lot, is like they're dragging this object that doesn't make any sense.
And they're like oh, well, 'cause everyone knows the bananas are flammable; I'm just putting them in, like oh God.
Like we never thought of that.
So catching what people are trying to do, getting them talking out loud is really good.
For the most part just watching, observing people and just, we don't, just try not to, there's a tendency you want to explain, like oh my God!
That's, that's going to be much better when you play.
Don't worry about that, that's going to be really great.
Just don't even bother with that.
Just let them, let them hate the game, 'cause you know, the next HOF they'll be like, oh my God, you got so much more improvements in.
It was great. OK.
This is going to be exciting. Whoo.
Schafer: Everybody will be playing the game and then meeting afterwards to say, I don't like this game.
Or I love this game.
Then we'll also have an anonymous survey where people can say I just don't like Tim, whatever.
Rice: So we're going to be doing that on the Cloud Colony this afternoon.
We've been working to kind of polish that level up a bit and get a lot of the details in there
that a first time player would need to be able to understand what's going on.
Franzke: So the main things that we need, just make it playable like, can you basically go through the entire Cloud Colony
without needing to load, reload the game and stuff like that.
Well, the major things that I am focused on is mostly crashes.
Really, it's kind of anything that seriously goes wrong under the hood where stuff just falls over and dies.
And it's good we got test support last week a little bit, so finally testers playing the game.
And looking at stuff and they find things which is good.
And then we can go in and fix those hopefully.
Rice: Yeah, we finally testers on the game.
So they've been, you know, finding bugs and putting them in our bug database for us to fix.
Lo: Before I started working as a tester, I would basically spend eight hours a day playing video games every day.
And now that it's my job, I come home and I'm like, I still look at a computer monitor
but I like, I don't really feel like playing games that even, that I've been excited for.
In fact, I think it actually made me less excited for certain games.
I'm only excited for like games that I really love, whereas before I was like, oh, I kind of like that game.
I might buy it.
And I'll play it.
It actually made me more selective of the games that I would actually beat nowadays.
And it takes a lot for a game for me to actually complete it now.
So yeah.
But before there was an issue where you pick up the ladder from that kid, and then you pick up the egg.
There would be, it would just crash the game for some reason.
There's that.
She just shoots in the top of ladder.
She doesn't have any pupils for some reason.
Franzke: Very often it's like, like a big shaky house in the way like if you push it at the wrong place it would fall over.
Just the way it is.
But yeah.
The trick is to find, the trick is to find all those places that the user can directly influence.
Directly or indirectly make sure that those are failsafe.
And any good.
Schafer: OK. Thank you for coming to our very first HOF.
We have the build, ready to go.
Some of you might have installed it already.
Oliver sent out a mail, a copied it on my mail so you can just install it on your computer.
And it should just magically run if you click on the "run" batch file.
It is a point-and-click graphic adventure.
Offscreen: What?
Offscreen Voice: They don't make those anymore.
Offscreen Voice: Those are dead.
Garner: Adventure games are not dead.
Schafer: Thank you.
Schafer: It has been almost one year since we launched our Kickstarter, by the way.
And now we're having our first HOF.
And so we have done a lot of stuff to get this adventure game engine up and running and working
and we have a several room area of what's called the Cloud Colony to play.
And we'd like to watch you play it.
Franzke: If it crashes like please come to any of the Red's programmers so we can help you, hopefully.
Also if it crashes during the game, which hopefully it won't, please don't.
If you press F1 and then go to "load" you can restore the previously, previous game state.
Schafer: OK, see you later.
We'll call you back in here in about half an hour.
Schafer: What, you didn't find a bug, did you?
Kipnis: What? Schafer: You didn't find a bug, did you?
Stapley: To soften the blow of failure.
Yeah!
Offscreen Voice: Add something on to that, some choices, right.
I sent one to them.
I think it was like, who's Jessie or something like that, right.
And then he said it, and I thought it would take me back to where I could ask something else, like something else about the towers.
I guess I'm going down, the talking tree or something like that.
Raz: Man, I don't know, I don't know what, like what's the first thing to get, what to say, how do I kill this guy?
Rice: All the other one's good.
Have you seen the one here, if you, go ahead, nothing.
Schafer: We aren't talking about, Rice: We're talking about you.
